bibl.title: [Letter] 1839 Jun. 10, Rural Rest [to] James King, Tuskaloosa, Alabama / Henry King
bibl.author: King, Henry
bibl.note: This is a letter dated June 10, 1839 from Henry King to his father James King. He tells his father that despite the cold weather, his cotton crops are tolerable, and the other crops are in fine order.

projectDesc.p: Created for the University of Tennessee Digital Library

editorialDecl.p: Quotation marks retained as data except inside q tags
Errors in transcription of the printed text controlled with X-Metal 3.0 spell-checker; text has also been thoroughly proofread.
Corrections and normalization represented by editorial tags.
Catchwords and directional notes such as "turn page over" have been omitted.

refsDecl.p: ID attributes provided for only those pages, chapters, or illustrations toward which a reference or figure points.

div1.p: With contentment I now seat myself to write you the nuse concerning diferent affaires Uncle Gannaway received yours dated 3rd of June Which I had the opportunity of reading and hearing that you all enjoyed your health and your trip so well and being kindly received by your relations and finding them all in good health I was truly glad. you stated that cousin Ann was has not recived recoived vered her strength yet which I was sorry to hear Mr Ship
The session of at salem ended on friday last on which day the examination was held the congregation was only tolerable large neithe did the students perform verry supperior in their studies.

Mr Ship and myself agrea verry well and manag has every affair in as good order as before you lefet yor cotton is onley tolerable the dry weather and cold together has stoped it from groing verry much it is as good as common it has been verry dry since you left the tobacco was set out after a smal shour but the most of it dyed your crop thruout the hole is as clear of grufs and weades as I ever knew it before at this time of the year

We will commence harvesting the wry this evening Your wry and wheat is uncommonly good oats is not so good We shall commence harvesting wheat the later part of the weak. I cannot relate you what w i l be done with the flour I have not seen unkle Gannaway since he received your letter I expect he wil state to you when he writess what he wil do with the flour he has give out the notion of sending it to Nashville your stocks of all kind remain sound and healthy. Your coalts has been tended to verry well
and are in fine order we have sold eight barels of corn las weak and Led Maj Ledbetter wil come after sixteen this weak We examined the bacon this morning and found it to remain sound.
Relate to mother her garden is in good order her cabbage and peas wartermelon vines snaps and all other things are in good order her chickens and fouls are groing verry well.

Tel Gran Mother her crop is tolerable clean and comes on finely Wilmington has been verry sick he is now on the mend the doctress Mariah has has been tending on him here this is the twelf day of his sickness.

Cousin Henry & mr Clinton left for the deastrick on monday last. Mr Brothers left on the fourt of June for north Carolina. Cousin Sam Butler arived here on wensday last with his lady Permelia thay ar both in fine health. W. F. Leiper arived at town las weak.
I have not time to write anything more I have to go to plowing this evening.

Give my love and respects to E. Grand mother & mother & Sister julia ann & to mr Parish & family. & Cuis Gen King & family and the enquireing friends of mine Mr Ship joins me in respect to you all. the children are all except Betty she has been alittle puny puny ever since you left She does not fret as much as she did at first.

Tell Juliann to me & not only to me but to her other friends and relation I think it wil improve her mind
Write & talk more than she has been in the habit of Father write to me soon. I remain in good health
div1.closer: I am your Sone H. A. J. King J. M. King tel F.A. "Bird to write to me if he has not Easter sends howdy to you all she says she has a heap of frute gathered for Mother. Dicy sends howdy to you. Cousin Lizzey and Martha sends their love and respects to you Cousin Martha and Brack are traveling backwards and fowards evry day Lizzy comes her but She so lonsome she cant stay long at a time Brack says you must bring him a poney. Sampson sends how dy to you all Aunt Jane received Mothers letter and wil write in a fu dayes
